												Rolling Sun feels more like a half-finished thought than a complete game.You're a rolling blue ball that can jump.  You'll roll through some pretty envionments but that's really all there is to it.  Challengers seem to be more co-incidental than by design.  And are mostly the challenge is caused by the camera.  The ball is centered in the screen even though every stage scrolls to the right.  At speed you can jump significantly further than the amount of screen that can be seen.  This is a problem because it reduces landing to luck.  Or rolling very very slowly.The physics sections are silly, I'm on the third of what looks like six stages (in less than half an hour) and nothing I've encounted so far has needed more thought than mashing the jump button.  As long as a piece of stage mesh has been touched you can jump again so wall climbing is doable.  With that said the physics on the floating rafts is annyoing because they bob up and down quite fast; and impart interia when jumped off making it impossible to judge far you'll jump.There are switches in the game.  There should not have been switches in the game.  Rolling into a swtich triggers a long switch rotation animation which is bad.  Worse is that whatever is switched doesn't start animating until after the switch animation is over.  This makes it easy to trigger a swtich, wait, roll out of the switch and then roll down a hole because the platforms raised by the switch are still raising.  What was the point?  Everyting switchable could have been left permanently in place without the aggravation of having to switch itThere is no gameplay challenge.  There is no fail condition.   You can fall down holes as often as you like, you'll be placed back at the start of the jump afterwards.  There are blue balls to collect but no indication of how many you need to collect - if any at all.  There is no timer so there is no time pressure.  Roll slowly and you should have no problem at all.Lastly I've run into a few glitches in the short time I've played.  Big red textures saying replace me, getting stuck behind the far side of the level.  And still having ball control whilst being rescued from a hole.  When given the strafe power-up the jump button re-binds from A to Y and strafe left becomes A; which is confusing.All-in-all Rolling Sun is not a game I'd recommend unless you're looking for something very laid back.

												Rolling Sun is a pretty game.A pretty bad one.This game might as well be an advertisement for the Cryengine’s resources; this game makes use of the Cryengine’s built-in resources to build a very pretty game. There’s beautiful landscapes, nice vistas, breathtaking rivers…And very little fun to be had, sadly.The game itself is a basic platformer. You control a spherical rock (possibly one of the stone spheres of Costa Rica, though it has ornate, glowing designs over the surface), and this matters – your rock will roll off of inclined slopes and has a fair bit of weight to it, which can tax some of the floating platforms. You start off having only the ability to roll around and jump, but over the course of the game you acquire the ability to double jump, air dash, and float (a much slower rate of descent) at the end of the second, third, and fourth levels respectively. While this sounds like it would add more gameplay, it honestly doesn’t; double jumping is the only ability that actually ends up important, and while you can use the other abilities, they’re never really necessary.The game consists of six fairly short levels with checkpoints distributed throughout them. The checkpoints are invisible but are mostly fairly generous, with the exception of the end of the final level, where it feels like half the level feeds off of one checkpoint. Not that it really matters in terms of difficulty; there’s only a few sections (such as one bit where there’s a moving platform underneath you that moves forward, reassembling itself before you – with or without you, if you’re too slow) that are really challenging platforming.Instead, the game has the lovely aspect of being “3D”, but being more like those old beat-’em-up games where you can move across a narrow space, but are mostly just moving left to right. However, if you move outside of these bounds, sometimes you’ll run into an invisible wall (okay), and sometimes you’ll get picked up by a floating Mayan mask which drags you back to the last checkpoint as if you fell off the level. This discourages you from poking around and exploring… not that there’s anything to explore, really.It takes until the third level of the game for it to do anything different, at which point it starts having sections that lead away from the camera into the distance (and, at a few painful points, head towards the camera, which thanks to the narrow field of view makes it hard to see where you’re going).Each level is filled with collectables – namely, a small floating rock with a blue field around it. They’re basically the game’s equivalent of coins, and they’re all over the place and mostly are used to show the proper way forward. If you collect every one of them in every level, you’ll unlock four bonus stages, which are shorter than the main levels and contain no checkpoints and the most challenging platforming in the game (though they’re still not all that hard).The further the game goes on, the weaker it gets; the first few levels feel fairly organic, but by the end of the game it often feels fairly arbitrary in terms of the level design, and the graphical quality also declines in the second half of the game, with pop-in issues rearing their head in the fourth level, followed by a rather drab nighttime level and a final snow level which is very generic and doesn’t even let your ball make paths in the snow in its wake.All in all, the game is just not worth it. It is about an hour and a half long if you want to get and play all the content, but there’s really just not much here; very basic platforming with mediocre at best level design consisting of platforms, bridges, and similar things over bottomless pits. There aren’t any enemies to speak of, no story… it is just a rather empty experience.Pretty, but pretty pointless to play.

												A lot of reviews complained about this game, especially the performance, but when I saw that it was 49 cents I decided to give it a shot. Performance: On my older mainstream enthusaist computer (i5-750, 760 GTX), I was getting good framerates on High graphics @ 1080p. I'd guess about 45-52 FPS. No screen tearing at all. At the beginning of stage 3 there is a really choppy part - there's some kind of optimization error there and I had to reduce it to Low graphics @ 800x600 -- luckily, no restart is required for any graphics changes so I just made it past that part and put the graphics back up. The game is a little short -- I beat it my first time playing, in about 1.5 hours. I died quite a few times but you start back at a checkpoint. There are some extras and bonus levels you can unlock. There doesn't seem to be any statisics tracking or goals. The game should have allowed you to try to beat your time and other things but there's nothing to it but to make it through the level. Also, it seems like the ball could have had a higher top speed especially downhill. They never explain why you are collecting the orbs but you'll notice that you need to collect all the orbs to unlock some bonus levels. The game doesn't have the polish of a Nintendo game or anything but it's also not $50.00. The graphics are very good especially on the last stage; the sound is just the basics; the music is okay but there are only 2 songs which alternate and get tiresome; the control is pretty good but they could have taken it a step further and changed the handling based on the surface like sand or ice; the physics are pretty good; the level design is pretty good; the ability to gain powers is pretty cool but mostly only the double jump gets used. It just seems like the developers got bored of working on this instead of spending the time it would take to make the game special and hold your interest. Pretty much the entire time I played I wished that they would have used this game world for an RPG or hack and slash platform game instead.I own thousands of games and don't normally play games for this long so I guess I enjoyed the challenge and appreciated that I didn't have to start over from the beginning when I died which allowing me to enjoy the entire game. Posted: November 14, 2016
												TLDR: This game is right at the threshold between a Thumbs Up and Thumbs Down review.  The early levels of the game are painful, but the final levels are quite fun.You roll around with a ball and must interact with the environment to progress.  You use your own weight to activate switches, raise and lower platforms, etc.  As a platformer, it is pretty basic, but it does well with what it can offer in terms of game play mechanics.Controls are difficult.  The ball is sluggish to respond to your inputs, occasionally not responding at all, and it seems physically impossible to roll in a straight line.  Anytime you jump, your ball seems to propel itself forward, almost always overshooting the platform you were aiming for.You unlock new abilities as you progress through the game: a double jump, dash forward and backwards, and a floating ability that slows the balls descent rate.  These abilities are never actually utilized by the level design, so it results in an inverted difficulty curve.  The early levels of the game are brutally difficult, but the later levels are much easier because you have a bunch of abilities to save yourself when you fall of the course.  I wonder if the sole purpose of the abilities are to offset the terrible controls.The environment is gorgeous, but there are too many foreground elements that constantly block your view.  The depth of field is also so narrow that you can't see what is coming immediately in front of you, often causing you to roll into a pit.  I sometimes found that I couldn't even tell where I was supposed to roll in order to continue the level.  Two of the ten levels in the game provide a view into the screen that shows what is coming in front of you.  I think the game would have been significantly more enjoyable if more levels used this perspective.This all combines for a game with a cool idea but poor execution. You'll go through a lot of trial and error gameplay that is far more frustrating than it is worth in the early levels.  However, the final few levels of the game are incredibly fun, particularly the final bonus level, and I'd say the game is worth playing for those levels alone.

												Here's the rundown:You're a rolling ball with tribal markings. Why? ♥♥♥♥ if I know.You've gotta roll through levels to the end. Why? ♥♥♥♥ if I know.You should pick up shiny orbs as you progress. Why? ♥♥♥♥ if I know.This game is a whole lotta nothing. It's pretty and it has physics, and that's about it. Level design is atrocious. It's 3D but would've been better in 2D. There's platform physics, but sometimes that means jumping on platforms floating in water. If the platform dips a little because you didn't land perfectly in the middle, guess what? Lakitu decides you fell in anyway and takes you back to a checkpoint.Whoa what a surprising twist! I thought I was gonna cross over that bridge but that Lakitu guy cut it and I fell into the water below! Then he fished me out! Why? ♥♥♥♥ if I know.You know what's a great idea? Make some levels with the progression towards the camera so you can't see where you're going!Make a double jump ability that kills all x-axis momentum!Make the game use 100% cpu power to get 40 fps! Who uses GPUs anyway.Make sure some inputs stay locked in so you can't control your speed sometimes!Make sure you reuse entire level sections, but at night time so they can't tell!Every loading screen and pause menu has the Cryengine splash on it. Sometimes you run into walls that have red blocks saying "REPLACE ME." This is a glorified tech demo that someone wanted to make a quick buck off of. My friend bought this for me for 50 cents to make me squirm.He succeeded.
